ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Reproducing the "hard" learning problem
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Jean-Baptiste, Thankyou for your feedback. I was mainly writing to make sure that I wasn t making any wrong assumptions about how the experiment should be

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Jean-Baptiste,

Thankyou for your feedback. 

I was mainly writing to ma=
ke sure that I wasn't making any wrong assumptions about how the experiment=
 should be performed.

I am glad to see that I am not far off the mark when=
 it comes to my implementation of the same problem space. 

I understand th=
at it is relatively irrelevant how I have implemented it as long as I use t=
he same implementation for each of the comparison implementations, however =
I just wanted to make sure I wasn't making wildly unjustified assumptions.
=

Thankyou for the link to your paper, I found it very interesting and now h=
ave another implementation that I can use to compare/validate my ideas. Hop=
efully I will be able to get to IROS this year and will see you there :-).
=

Cheers,

Aidan


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: mandor@happycoder=
s.org 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, September 21, 2009 7:23 =
PM
  Subject: Re: [neat] Reproducing the "hard" learning problem


    Hi,
=

  "Aidan Morgan" <aidos@...> wrote :

  | I am trying to replicat=
e the "hard" learning problem from the
  | behavioural diversity papers tha=
t have recently been discussed on
  | the mailing list. I have a few ideas =
I would like to try out, but I
  | would like to be able to compare them to=
 the original research to
  | see if I can get any improvement.

  | I have=
 two questions to ask of those of you who have tried
  | recreating this:

=
  I have recreated it in a slightly different setup (the change were
  made=
 to simplify the implementation in my framework and the potential
  impleme=
ntation on a real robot). In my experience, the results were
  easy to repr=
oduce and does not depends much on the details.

  For details about my imp=
lementation, you can check the paper that I
  will present at the IROS work=
shop ("Exploring new horizons of
  Evolutionary Design of Robots", see the =
next message):
  http://chronos.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/papers/novelty_based_m=
ultiobjectivization.pdf

  | 1. How big is the area? I have got all of the =
internal "walls" in
  | place in scale to the total size of the map, howeve=
r I would like to
  | get a rough idea of the width/height of the "map". I =
understand that
  | this should all be relative, but without some sort of "=
scale factor"
  | for my map from the original I don't know what is a reaso=
nable
  | amount of space for the agent to move etc. Currently my world is =
120
  | x 115 units big, and the agent can move anywhere up to 2.5 units pe=
r
  | time period.

  My hard map is 500x500 px, that are transformed into =
a 600x600 units
  maze. The radius of my robot is 20 units. Each wheel can =
make up 2
  units per time step and I used 1500 time-steps for the whole
  =
simulation.

  | 2. I also am interested in how the outputs of the neural n=
etwork are
  | interpreted. I know from the papers that there are two outpu=
t
  | neurons, one for forward/backward and one for left/right. Currently
 =
 | I am interpreting these as output < 0.5 =3D turn left, output > 0.5 =3D
=
  | turn right and the same for forward/backward. This is leading to a
  | =
pretty constant behaviour of moving in circles around the map,
  | always t=
urning left - so I am wondering how other people have
  | interpreted the o=
utput result to get a more intelligent movement
  | pattern.

  I used a di=
fferent robot than in the original paper. The main reason
  was to have out=
puts similar to the ones you could use on a small
  mobile robot. I have tw=
o outputs: 
  - speed of the right wheel
  - speed of the left wheel

  I c=
an send you my source code in you think it can be useful. 

  Best regards,=

  -- 
  Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
  http://animatlab.lip6.fr/~mouret
 =
 tel : (+33) 6 28 35 10 49
